report_title: Industry Report: Forklift and Conveyor Manufacturing
executive_summary: Forklift and conveyor manufacturing is a mature industry with clearly defined markets and widely accepted product lines with few substitutes outside of importing. Various downstream markets drive demand for such a diverse set of product lines. Heavy infrastructure construction and inventory management primarily go with the need for forklifts, while freight and manufacturing industries make up most of the need for conveyor systems. The international trade market for forklift and conveyor products will also account for a large portion of industry revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Business investment in machinery and industrial equipment drove demand for forklifts and conveyor systems used in manufacturing and inventory management. Increased demand from wholesalers and retailers catering to the increased demands of e-commerce sales helped drive the need for materials handling equipment used in storage, transportation and logistics. The recent boom in utility construction significantly boosted the need for crucial equipment like forklifts and conveyors, particularly those used in the construction industry. The rapid expansion and growth in the nonresidential construction sector have significantly increased the need for moving stairways.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: COVID-19 breaks the streak of growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The pandemic triggered reduced economic activity across the United States, resulting in a more rapid deterioration in the need from the industry's largest downstream markets. The volatility in supply chains significantly impacts the logistics and profitability in nonresidential construction, mining, retail, manufacturing and export sectors. Stringent social distancing measures halted investments in new machinery and equipment.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Competition from abroad is impeding domestic growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As the US dollar appreciates, the international competitiveness of domestically produced goods, like forklifts and conveyors, decreases. Persistent trade tensions between the United States and China have amplified the challenges of the forklift and conveyor manufacturing industry, leading to a depression in exports and increased uncertainty. The lower production costs in South Korea and Germany result in cheaper goods that appeal to foreign markets, including the United States.

To battle persistently high inflation rates across the US Economy, the Federal Reserve announced that they would conduct contractionary monetary policy until inflation reigned in. As a result, interest rates rose. The rising interest rates affected two major downstream markets directly. Demand from both residential and nonresidential markets plummeted in 2022 and is expected to continue to fall through the end of the period since the Fed has offered no sign of lowering the rates.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Bouncing back from the economic slump
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Demand for hoist systems, industrial trucks, elevators and other industry products did not disappear but instead was depressed because of unfavorable economic conditions in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. As the economy stabilizes, industrial production and construction are expected to boom in the coming years. The need for forklifts and conveyors will likely expand with the expansion of these downstream markets. Exports will likely expand to satisfy a more significant revenue share as a depressed US Dollar will boost the need from foreign markets.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Downstream markets will improve and expand
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Forklift and conveyor manufacturers benefit from more robust needs from its major downstream markets, including freight and transportation, manufacturing, construction, mining and retail. US manufacturing, wholesale and retail companies will devote significant resources to improving inventory management to better compete. Material-handling equipment manufacturers will form joint ventures with material-handling consultants, information technology and logistics management companies to add value to their product range and secure their customer base.

The push to boost battery life efficiency and reduce emissions through hybrid vehicles has dominated the industry's lift truck manufacturers. Technological innovations are designed to attract business by reducing ongoing operating and maintenance costs after purchase, though it is more expensive at the point of sale. Several forklift and conveyor manufacturers plan to significantly expand their global operations in response to emerging markets' escalating infrastructure-related demands worldwide.

The manufacturing sector increasingly embraces environmental sustainability, prioritizing eco-friendly production methods to reduce the ecological footprint and minimize resource depletion, pollution and waste generation. The emphasis on electric forklifts and energy-efficient conveyors in warehouse operations promises substantial energy savings compared to traditional equipment, reflecting an increased commitment to environmental sustainability in the industry. Sustainable materials and manufacturing methods that induce minimal environmental impact are increasingly gaining prominence.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry manufacture equipment used to lift or move materials. Major products and services include forklifts, conveyor equipment manufacturing, cranes, hoist systems, industrial trucks, stacker machinery and all related parts and upkeep of products. This industry excludes operators that manufacture construction-type tractors and cranes, as these companies are included in the Construction Machinery Manufacturing industry (IBISWorld report 33312).

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

key_trends: Barriers to entry are relatively low despite being capitally intensive at the start. This allows new entrants to emerge and compete with the more prominent, established manufacturers.

The market is highly fragmented, which gives way to specialized companies. Major manufacturers focus and dominate in a handful of product categories, so the rest of the market is available for niche companies.
Rising interest rates dampened nonresidential and residential demand for forklifts
Interest rates are expected to stall in 2024, potentially stimulating demand from downstream construction markets.
Machines and production are becoming more efficient as technology advances
The heavy equipment and tools companies use are reducing costs and allowing profit to expand.
Competition rises as the construction sector recovers
Construction companies are in search of machinery that is lower priced and lower in cost
Manufacturing companies are introducing new advanced electrical machinery
The push to reduce carbon emissions is forcing companies to upgrade their equipment.
The Clean Air Act is raising costs
The US Environmental Protection Agency is attempting to reduce the emission of air pollutants from manufacturing companies.
Tariffs on foreign suppliers level the playing field
This enables local manufacturers to compete, as the artificially inflated prices more closely match their costs.
Wages are becoming a larger share of the revenue
More advanced equipment requires highly skilled workers that must be compensated for their work.
Prices of steel and oil remain relatively high
These are the main commodities purchased by manufacturers, which cuts into profit if they are unable to pass along costs.
Operations remain near car manufacturers
The Great Lakes have served as a prime location as mass car-producing companies such as Ford and General Motors depend heavily on forklifts and conveying equipment.

market_segmentation.segment_description: The manufacturing industry converts raw materials into goods with the help of machines and equipment. Forklifts and conveyors are essential to the day-to-day operations of manufacturers. The automotive industry experienced significant distress due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Reduced global demand has triggered a drop in commodity prices and a surge in the dollar's value. Also, heightened trade tensions compound the industry's challenges, creating an extremely challenging business environment across similar markets worldwide.

The mining sector involves the extraction of minerals from the surface of the earth. Conveyors and lifts are essential to the movement and maintenance of mined materials. Mining for minerals, like coal, has declined due to regulatory pressures and price competition from other energy sources, leading to muted growth among manufacturers.

The construction industry consists of residential, non-residential and utility construction. Construction markets regularly use forklifts for heavy lifting and the transportation of building materials. The two most prominent industries in this sector are residential and non-residential. Financing large expansion projects has become much more costly because of rising interest rates. One bright spot for the construction market is the growing need for utility construction, which is expected to strengthen through the end of 2024.

Freight-handling industries use industrial truck and trailer conveyor systems, hoists and forklift equipment to move freight from its origin in warehouses to its destination. Waste management facilities also generate significant and steady revenue. Demand from warehouses and storage facilities has grown as US consumers have increased their need for low-priced imported goods and online shopping.

The paper industry includes paper mills that use wood as raw material to produce various types of paper products. Paper mills rely heavily on industrial machinery like forklifts and comprehensive conveyor systems to move large quantities of paper products. Still, this industry is slowly declining with the rise of e-commerce and the subsequent reduction in demand for physical paper.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Forklifts and Industrial Trucks, Trailers and Stackers
products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes forklifts, powered bulk-material moving equipment (think stacking machines, trailers and hydraulic-lift platforms) and separately sold parts that can be broken down into internal combustion and electric-powered machines. Demand for lithium-ion battery-powered forklifts will continue significant growth. Rising individual consumption and advancements in warehousing and logistics have increased the need for electric machines, accounting for most segment sales. Increased e-commerce has boosted demand for efficient electrical trucks to facilitate the inventory management needs of large online companies.

Conveyors include unit handling, bulk material handling and other types of belts, non-belt, gravity and trolley conveying systems for manufacturing, warehousing, shipping and agricultural uses. The agricultural sector's use of these products provides a steady source of demand, while manufacturers and shippers experience magnified efficiency gains from using industry products when consumption is increasing. Improved automation technology has created further demand in the sector, as automated technology saves money in the long run despite having a higher up-front cost.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Overhead Cranes, Hoists and Monorail Systems
products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes aerial work platforms, overhead traveling cranes, winches and automobile hoists, which are primarily used in industrial settings such as manufacturing or warehousing. Demand for overhead cranes has contracted as overall slow growth was offset by sharply contracting industrial and manufacturing activity in 2020. Possible revenue jumps will occur thanks to greater commercial development and a rising urbanization rate.

Elevators and escalators include freight and passenger elevators, escalators, moving walkways, dumbwaiters and the associated parts and attachments. These goods are installed in large warehouses, commercial buildings and urban residential buildings. Growing commercial and industrial construction activity has spurred elevators and escalators' demand. Increased building activity will continue driving the need for elevators and escalators as a critical component of new buildings in growing cities.

tier_1_suppliers: Screw, Nut & Bolt Manufacturing in the US
Engine & Turbine Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Iron & Steel Manufacturing in the US
Ferrous Metal Foundry Products in the US
tier_1_buyers: Power Tools & Other General Purpose Machinery Manufacturing in the US
Industrial Machinery & Equipment Wholesaling in the US
Industrial Equipment Rental & Leasing in the US
Construction Machinery Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Transportation and Warehousing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Manufacturers, particularly those in the automotive sector, use conveyor belts and forklift equipment to produce and handle goods at various stages in the production process. An increase in the industrial production index indicates growing manufacturing activity, which drives demand for new or replacement conveyor belts and forklift equipment. Declines in the industrial production index pose a potential threat to forklift and conveyor manufacturers.

international_trade_points.trade_title: LESS COSTLY GOODS FROM FOREIGN COUNTRIES
international_trade_points.trade_description: Canada, Germany, Mexico and China provide low-cost substitute goods since these countries have lower labor costs, and that's why the United States buys from them. While the US Dollar has lost value thanks to inflation, it remains strong in comparison to export destinations. Foreign goods are still relatively less expensive than domestic goods, so domestic buyers have a higher purchasing power in foreign economies, which bolsters imports.

international_trade_points.trade_title: SUPPLY CHAIN CLOGS DUE TO COVID-19
international_trade_points.trade_description: The congestion at ports was caused by cargo ships taking longer than usual to unload goods due to soaring demand, resulting in sluggish import growth. Imports have recovered since the pandemic as the congestion issue was resolved. Still, inefficiency across the supply chain has caused domestic consumers to depend more on local goods, slightly offsetting the otherwise massive growth imports experienced.

international_trade_points.trade_title: UNITED STATES-MEXICO-CANADA AGREEMENT (USMCA) SECURES TRADING PARTNERS
international_trade_points.trade_description: The USMCA ensures that Mexico and Canada are continuously among the top buyers of US exports. Both countries have hiked imports of US-produced forklifts and conveyors in recent years as their domestic manufacturing sectors gain traction. Both countries benefit from geographic proximity as transportation is quick and inexpensive. This is also exemplified by companies concentrating their operations in the Great Lakes region. Moving closer to a major exporter lowers the friction of shipping.

international_trade_points.trade_title: APPRECIATING DOLLAR AND RISING STEEL AND OIL PRICES HINDERS EXPORTS
international_trade_points.trade_description: The appreciation of the US dollar relative to the currencies of major trading partners makes domestic goods more expensive and less appealing. After a significant boost in 2023, overall imports have risen to satisfy one-third of domestic demand. Increased global steel and oil prices and imposed tariffs on steel imports have resulted in significant cost pressures for forklift and conveyor manufacturers. Consequently, they have been forced to raise their product prices to maintain profitability.

business_locations.location: THE GREAT LAKES AND ITS CLOSE DOWNSTREAM MANUFACTURERS
business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region has been a historically dominant epicenter for manufacturing in the United States thanks to its proximity to manufacturing companies that rely on forklifts and conveyors. Major local automotive companies, including Ford and General Motors, use forklifts and conveyor equipment to mass-produce their products. Also, companies with a sizeable exporting presence set up in the Great Lakes region because it is close to Canada, the largest exporter of household goods.

business_locations.location: THE SOUTHEAST, WHERE TAXES ARE LOW TO NONE
business_locations.location_description: Overhead traveling cranes, hoists, winches, industrial trucks, tractors, trailers and stackers are the key product segments that significantly contribute to the economic growth of this particular region. Recent legislation in Florida providing sales tax exemptions for manufacturers on machinery and equipment purchases has increased industry concentration. This favorable law offers manufacturers a significant cost advantage, encouraging them to establish or expand their operations within the state.

business_locations.location: MINING FOR MINERALS IN THE PLAINS
business_locations.location_description: The Plains consists of many mining companies that extract coal, metals and industrial minerals, relying on forklifts, conveyors and hoists to carry out these operations. Because of resource availability and logistical advantages, the industries that focus on industrial truck and overhead crane manufacturing are predominantly concentrated in the plains regions.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) imposes stringent regulations limiting the pollution emitted during manufacturing processes. This directly impacts the makers of lift trucks, forklifts and other engine-powered vehicles, requiring them to adhere to these rules. In addition to federal EPA guidelines, these manufacturers must comply with the varying regulations set forth by local and state governments.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Coronavirus Aid, Relief and Economic Security (CARES) Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Coronavirus Aid, Relief and Economic Security (CARES) Act includes provisions for temporary sick leave benefits to assist workers during the pandemic. However, the law does not apply uniformly to all businesses. It excludes companies with fewer than 50 employees and those with more than 500, leaving many workers potentially without these benefits.

The 29 CFR 1910.178(a) regulation manages safety issues associated with manufacturing industrial trucks such as forklifts. This rule is essential to the manufacturing sector as it outlines definite expectations about fire protection systems, design specifications and maintenance schedules. Conformance to these regulatory standards ensures that the produced equipment is safe for consumer use.

factors_increased_barrier: Companies face a mountain of safety, environmental, trade and regional regulations that must be strictly followed in order to participate.

basis_points.basis_description: Big-name corporations offer a variety of products that are the most common in downstream markets, while smaller niche companies specialize in smaller markets.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Major manufacturers have a competitive advantage
concentration_points.concentration_description: It's challenging to enter the forklift and conveyor market because of the significant capital investment required in manufacturing and developing the products, driving away the competition.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Product Variation Gives Way to Niche Companies
concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry remains relatively unconcentrated since the top companies can only cost-effectively produce a few different products, creating gaps and cavities in the industry that specialized companies fill.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: A substantial proportion of expenditure can be attributed to high-cost commodities in several industries. Examples include the costly procurement of resources like steel and engines and critical technology developments like computers.

As technology advances, the wages of highly skilled workers involved in the creation of software and the design of products will invariably expand. This growth is due to the increasing demand for artificial intelligence, machine learning and other technological fields. The high-complexity tasks performed by these workers command premium remunerations.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: THE LARGEST PLAYERS BENEFIT FROM ECONOMIES OF SCALE
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Top companies can produce at a volume large enough that they enjoy economies of scale, resulting in higher profits. Some small companies have achieved efficient production and can yield similar profits as the more prominent manufacturers.

To mitigate climate change, many manufacturing companies are transitioning to electrically powered machines. This significantly reduces carbon emissions, contributing to the global effort to save our environment from further degradation. These machines are more expensive but due to the increased efficiency they provide, companies have been able to save on cost in the long run.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Successful forklift and conveyor manufacturers depend heavily on skilled laborers and engineers to design the products and create technology packages.

volatility_points.volatility_title: SUCCESS FOR MANUFACTURERS IS DEPENDENT ON THE PERFORMANCE OF DOWNSTREAM MARKETS
volatility_points.volatility_description: Most revenue relies upon downstream demand from other parts of the economy, including mining, freight, construction and manufacturing. These areas are cyclical and reliant on their downstream forces, creating a web of industries that need to perform well for forklift and conveyor manufacturers to observe their revenue numbers flourish.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Economic Uncertainty Plays a Big Role
volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry is sensitive to global economic and exchange rate trends since domestic companies rely on other countries' products, including steel and crude oil. Appreciation of the US dollar has made domestic goods more expensive for foreigners and decreased exports, lowering industry revenue and demand. The economic impact of COVID-19 caused forklift and conveyor manufacturing revenue to slump as the need for industry products fell, though it bounced back over the past few years.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Manufacturers have invested in developing specialized products for emerging export markets, such as space-saving elevator installation options for the Asia-Pacific market and lower-usage electric lift trucks. The rise in advanced automation technology has triggered a surge in demand from the agricultural sector. These improvements significantly enhance productivity, management, and overall efficiency of farming operations.

FAQs.question: Are there opportunities for your company in exports?
FAQs.answer: Some industry companies derive a significant portion of their revenue from export sales.

FAQs.question: What are the OSHA regulations relevant to this industry?
FAQs.answer: The 29 CFR 1910.178(a) regulation manages safety issues associated with manufacturing industrial trucks such as forklifts. This rule outlines definite expectations about fire protection systems, design specifications and maintenance schedules.

FAQs.question: What industry assistance is available?
FAQs.answer: The Conveyor Equipment Manufacturers Association (CEMA) has consistently provided set standards, technical details, safety labels and necessary safety information to conveyor manufacturers since 1933.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: This industry's performance is procyclical. Downstream demand increases in line with industrial production, construction and shipping activity.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing heavily in R&D to meet the evolving needs of downstream industries?
FAQs.answer: Operators in this industry have poured resources into improving their products' energy efficiency. They have also invested significantly in data collection and analytics capacity for their conveyor equipment, in addition to semi-automating certain lift trucks.

FAQs.question: Has your company located near key downstream customers to reduce shipping costs?
FAQs.answer: To compete, smaller industry operators have strategically located near key customers. In general, operators tend to be concentrated in manufacturing hubs, such as the Great Lakes region.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: For this industry, the savings on lower-skilled labor due to automation have been surpassed by the increased hiring of more skilled and expensive workers.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to safeguard your company's proprietary information?
FAQs.answer: It is routine for operators in this industry to patent their products and designs. Moreover, cybersecurity has become an increasing concern.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to comply with new environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: Operators are already investing in more energy-efficient/greener products to keep ahead of new regulations and meet downstream client demands. Operators' own production processes must also comply with emissions and waste disposal regulations.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Operators in this industry endure scrutiny from OSHA due to the potential workplace hazards involved in manufacturing industrial machinery.

FAQs.question: How often do your customers purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Most customers purchase products from this industry as long-lived capital assets, so they do not replace equipment often. However, significant technological advances may induce more frequent replacement.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profitability compare to that of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profitability is determined by efficiency of operations, with larger operators benefiting from economies of scale and smaller operators benefiting from lower capital intensity.

FAQs.question: Do you have access to the latest available and most efficient technology and techniques? Is your technical expertise to a world standard?
FAQs.answer: Access to internationally competitive technology through in-house R&D or licensing agreements gives industry operators an edge over the competition. Operators continue R&D efforts on better fuel economy for lift trucks and data analytics for conveyors.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain product quality? Do you have systems in place to keep standards high and continually updating?
FAQs.answer: Effective quality control adds value by ensuring consistent quality under brand names. Operators offer maintenance and consulting services to enhance quality and inform R&D.

FAQs.question: Which niches, if any, do you cater to? How can you diversify your product mix? How do you keep track of the latest trends?
FAQs.answer: Access to niche markets increases revenue through specialization, but may limit expansion. Staying abreast of technological trends is paramount as downstream markets seek operational efficiency through enhanced machinery.

FAQs.question: How have past fluctuations in exchange rates affected your company? Do your products compete with imports?
FAQs.answer: As the trade-weighted index increases, US exports become less competitive internationally, diminishing demand for US goods.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by changes in demand from nonresidential construction? How much of your business comes from this sector?
FAQs.answer: Office, retail, industrial, hotel, hospital, airport and seaport building activity affects demand for elevators, moving walkways and other forklift and conveyor equipment used in construction.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your revenue is derived from freight and logistics businesses? How do you plan to take advantage of this opportunity?
FAQs.answer: Systems, forklifts and hoists are used to load freight for transportation. Wholesalers and shipping companies constitute important downstream markets for the industry.
